title: AB 2891
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 25173.7 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to allocate funds from the Toxic Substances Control Account for site remediation costs in the General Fund. An amount sufficient for estimated costs and a minimum of $10,750,000 will be appropriated annually. The curr_chunk discusses the allocation of funds for various purposes, including site remediation costs, administration fees, and pollution prevention measures. It includes specific amounts designated for each purpose, such as $400,000 for the Expedited Site Remediation Trust Fund, reimbursement of administration costs, and $1,050,000 for a pollution prevention program. Funds not appropriated for specified purposes may be used for other purposes outlined in Section 25173.6(b), with adjustments made annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The department can reduce allocated amounts with legislative approval if there are insufficient funds in the Toxic Substances Control Account. Suspend transfer specified in paragraph (3) of subdivision (a) if no orphan shares pending payment under former Chapter 6.85 (Section 25396). The department must provide an annual report to the Legislature estimating funding needed for direct site remediation costs at state and federal Superfund orphan sites. This includes costs for the current budget year and the following two years, covering remedial actions and ongoing maintenance obligations. Section 25205.6 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to define "organization" and require the department to provide the board with a schedule of codes for organizations dealing with hazardous materials in California. The schedule includes identification codes from the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) or North American Industry Classification System (NAICS). Each organization identified in the schedule must pay an annual fee based on the number of employees:
- $200 for 50-75 employees
- $350 for 75-100 employees
- $700 for 100-250 employees
- $1,500 for 250-500 employees
- $2,800 for 500-1,000 employees
- $9,500 for 1,000+ employees. The fee imposed on organizations is based on the number of employees and must be paid in accordance with the Revenue and Taxation Code. The revenue generated will be deposited in the Toxic Substances Control Account and used for specified purposes upon legislative appropriation. The number of employees is determined by those employed in the state for more than 500 hours in the previous calendar year. The State Board of Equalization adjusts fee rates annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The state is obligated to pay specified costs for removal and remedial actions under the federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. The fee rates are adjusted annually by the State Board of Equalization based on the Consumer Price Index to fund the state's obligations under the federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Nonprofit corporations providing residential care are exempt from this section. The changes made to this section by the act of the 2005–06 Regular Session of the Legislature shall not increase fee revenues in the 2006–07 fiscal year.
